repnme.cdata!:
India - Gujarat Emergency Earthquake
            Reconstruction Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Gujarat Emergency
            Earthquake Reconstruction Project for India were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was moderate, Bank performance was satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: 1) fund disbursement linked to
            construction progress (for individual construction)
            facilitates effective use of funds. In the absence of this
            link, there is a risk that beneficiaries may use funds for
            purposes other than the intended use; 2) the projects
            approach to the reconstruction of housing are now standard
            across South Asia disaster management housing reconstruction
            programs and have influenced housing reconstruction in Aceh,
            Indonesia. Lessons learnt from the project have been
            integrated into those projects; 3) the Government of
            Gujarat's (GoG's) 2003 promulgation of the Gujarat
            Disaster Management Act, provided for the formation and
            mandate of the Gujarat State Disaster Management Authority
            (GSDMA). The formation of the GSDMA allowed for quick policy
            decisions during project implementation, for the
            co-ordination of a multitude of line departments (without
            questions of authority) and for the integration of
            longer-term disaster management into the disaster
            reconstruction. In the absence of the Act and the GSDMA
            integrated disaster management would not have been possible;
            and 4) disasters require quick reconstruction to meet the
            needs of affected people. This can contradict with long-term sustainability.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Malaria Control, Orissa Health
            Systems Development, Tuberculosis Control, Women and Child
            Development, and Gujarat Emergency Earthquake Reconstruction
            Projects : proposed restructuring of five projects for polio eradication

abstracts.cdata!:
This report seeks the Executive
            Directors' approval to restructure five projects:
            Malaria Control Project (Cr. 29640-IN), the Orissa Health
            Systems Development Project (Cr. NO41 0-IN), the
            Tuberculosis Control Project (Cr. 29360-IN), the Women and
            Child Development Project (Cr. N0420-IN), and the Gujarat
            Emergency Earthquake Reconstruction Project (Cr. 36370-IN)
            The report proposes reallocating SDR 65.35 million
            (approximately US$ 96 million equivalent) of credit proceeds
            to support urgent financing needs for a polio eradication
            program in India. Two of these projects (Orissa Health
            Systems Development and Women and Child Development) are
            financed through Interim Trust Funds (ITF). Approval is
            being sought for these two projects through the
            International Development Association since ITF credits have
            become part of IDA'S general resources, and IDA may act
            for itself with regard to such resources rather than as
            administrator for ITF. The proposed restructuring will
            assist the Government of India in eradicating poliomyelitis
            from the country--this will contribute to global polio
            eradication, and supplement the ongoing Immunization
            Strengthening Project (Cr. 33400-IN) and the Supplemental
            Credit to this project (Cr. 33401-IN) by financing
            additional polio eradication activities required on an
            emergency basis by the Government of India. In all five
            projects, the proposed restructuring would neither
            compromise the original objectives nor affect their overall
            economic viability.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Gujarat Emergency Earthquake
            Reconstruction Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Gujarat Emergency Earthquake
            Reconstruction Program Project's main objectives are:
            promoting sustainable recovery to the earthquake affected
            areas; and laying the foundation for sustainable disaster
            management capacity in Gujarat. There are four project
            components. The first finances the implementation of
            owner-driven housing recovery plans initiated under the
            ongoing immediate phase (Phase 1) for the partially damaged
            and fully collapsed houses in the affected rural and urban
            areas. The second component funds for repairing,
            strengthening, rehabilitating, reconstructing, and upgrading
            damaged public buildings, roads and bridges, and dams and
            irrigation infrastructure in the earthquake-affected areas;
            2) retrofitting undamaged government administration
            buildings and critically important public buildings and
            preparing detailed engineering documents for retrofitting
            key bridges; and 3) constructing buildings and control rooms
            needed to foster State emergency management as well as
            setting up the Gujarat Institute of Disaster Management
            (GIDM) and the Institute for Seismic Research. The third
            component ensures the participation of earthquake-affected
            communities establishing village-level subcenters to build
            capacity for earthquake-resistant construction,
            strengthening local government mechanisms, gender
            sensitization, and community-based disaster preparedness
            programs. The fourth component finances the establishment of
            a professional emergency management program.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Gujarat Emergency Earthquake
            Reconstruction Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment for the
            Gujarat Emergency Earthquake Reconstruction Project
            describes negative environmental impacts and measures to be
            taken to mitigate them. An awareness campaign will be
            conducted so that excavated materials at each site will be
            managed properly, and storage/piling is done away from water
            bodies and drainage channels. Villages will be involved in
            the planning and site selection. No forestland, ecological
            protected areas, national parks, wildlife sanctuaries, or
            known habitats of flora/fauna will be acquired for public
            use, nor will environmental resources be overused as
            building materials. Pollution from and in the construction
            camps, loss of roadside vegetation, change in water
            availability, pollution of riverbeds (where bridges are
            built), management of borrow areas/quarries, and pollution
            from hot-mix and batching plants will be governed and/or
            alleviated using standard guidelines for
            mitigation/management of construction-related impacts in
            contractual provisions. All construction codes for buildings
            safety and worker safety will be strictly implemented.
            During construction activities, standard construction codes
            for minimizing environmental concerns will be used to offset
            increase of the catchment/submergence area due to increased
            dam height, and spillover and dust from haulage, storage,
            and handling of earth. The codes include provisions for
            efficient storage, haulage, handling of earthwork, dust
            suppression, and erosion control.

India - Gujarat Emergency Earthquake
